results.title: London
results.creator_credit: Patrick Keiller, Keith Griffiths and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: A ‘documentary’ portrait of the capital which can variously be described as an ‘essay’ or a ‘journal’ (an interesting comparison could be made with Jarman’s ‘essay’ - The Last of England). Images of London in 1992 are accompanied by an unnamed fictional narrator, a friend and former lover of Robinson. The latter is attempting to research the city’s artistic past and support alternative paths that the city’s history might have taken. The film is made up of three ‘expeditions’ and other mini-journeys on foot. The paths taken are inspired by literary-historical concerns but contemporary political events intrude. The two reflect on how political decisions might impact upon the city’s future.

results.title: Australia's birds : Oceans
results.creator_credit: Grant Young and GEO Wildlife Documentaries
results.brief_description: Oceans make up about four-fifths of the Earths surface, and there are many kinds of birds that spend their lives roaming these vast expanses between continents, seldom finding themselves even within sight of land. Many come ashore only to nest. In size these ocean wanderers range from the albatrosses - some with wingspans nearing three metres, among the largest birds that fly - to the tiny storm-petrel, little bigger than a starling. This video tells the story of a cross-section of some of the more common and representative of these fascinating ocean wanderers. Birds discussed are: Wandering Albatross; Providence Petrel; Black-winged Petrel; Flesh-footed Shearwater; Wedge-tailed Shearwater; Australasian Gannet; Masked Booby; Sooty Tern; Grey Noddy; Brown Noddy; White Tern; Red-tailed Tropicbird.

results.title: Paws
results.creator_credit: Karl Zwicky, Vicki Watson, Andrena Finlay, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Latent Image Productions, AFFC and PolyGram Film International
results.brief_description: Zac (Nathan Cavaleri) never wanted a dog, until he met a special dog called PC. PC’s master, Alex, is murdered by the evil associates of his ex wife, Anja. Anja and Alex used to live in Iceland where Alex wrote computer programs; the only problem was that Anja stole her husband’s programs and sold them. Alex managed to escape to Australia with 1 million dollars and PC. Before his death Alex attaches a computer disc to PC’s collar and sends him off to a friend. PC ends up in the care of her neighbour, Zac. Through the assistance of a computer which translates dog noises into a human voice, Zac and PC become quickly become friends as they try and avoid Anja and find the 1 million dollars before her. Also starring Norman Kaye, Sandy Gore, Caroline Gillmer, Emilie Francois and Billy Connolly as the voice of PC.

results.title: Miracle at sea : the Tony Bullimore rescue
results.creator_credit: Guy Norris, Richard Dennison, John Gau Productions and Orana Films
results.brief_description: The Southern Ocean is the harshest place on earth. It is the Everest of the oceans and, for centuries, it has been the mariner’s ultimate challenge. This documentary reveals Tony Bullimore’s struggle to cling to life in the darkness of the freezing hull of his capsized 60ft yacht, Exide Challenger. He was two months into the Vendee Globe Around the World Yacht Race, 1300 miles south of Australia when disaster struck and his yacht overturned in 60ft waves. So began the biggest air sea rescue in the history of the Royal Australian Air Force. It would involve four aircraft, six air crew and one hundred and ninety hours of flying.

results.title: Australia's birds : Woodlands
results.creator_credit: Grant Young, Terence Lindsey and GEO Wildlife Documentaries
results.brief_description: Most Australian woodlands are dominated by trees of a particular group - the eucalypts. Familiar to all Australians these distinctive trees have a number of special characteristics that set them apart, and these unique characteristics provide a wealth of challenges and opportunities for the birds that inhabits Australian woodlands, resulting in one of the richest and most diverse bird communities on the continent. This video focuses on the life histories and special feeding behaviours of 23 species of Australian woodland birds. Birds discussed are: Yellow Robin; Laughing Kookaburra; Grey Burtcherbird; Rufous Songlark; Pallid Cuckoo; Rufous Whistler; Rainbow Bee-eater; Sacred Kingfisher; White-winged Chough; Restless Flycatcher; Speckled Warbler; Peaceful Dove; Double-barred Finch; Varied Sittella; White-throated Treecreeper; Shriketit; Fuscous Honeyeater; Spotted Pardalote; Noisy Friarbird; Regent Honeyeater; Scarlet Honeyeater; Painted Honeyeater; Mistletoe Bird.

results.title: Australia's birds: Wetlands
results.creator_credit: Terence Lindsey, Grant Young and GEO Wildlife Documentaries
results.brief_description: Once wetlands covered a third of Australia, but that was a million years ago, and now the continent is very much drier. Australia’s remaining extensive wetlands are more or less restricted to the southeast, southwest, and the tropical north. Nevertheless, Australia has an extremely rich and varied aquatic avifauna, and its lakes, swamps and rivers are thronged with many species of birds. This video explores the fascinating relationship between 28 Australian aquatic birds and the wetlands, temporary or permanent, in which they spend their lives. Birds discussed are: Black Swan; Pied Stilt; Red-necked Avocet; Whiskered Tern; Grey Teal; Pink-eared Duck; Australasian Shoveler; Freckled Duck; Clamorous Reed-Warbler; Little Grassbird; Baillons Crake; Australian Crake; Spotless Crake; Buff-banded Rail; Eurasian Coot; Dusky Moorhen; Blue-billed Duck; Hardhead; Musk Duck; Australasian Grebe; Hoary-headed Grebe; Red-kneed Dotterel; Black-fronted Plover; Royal Spoonbill; Yellow-billed Spoonbill; White-faced Heron; Pacific Heron; Straw-necked Ibis.

results.title: Wilde's domain
results.creator_credit: Charles Tingwell, Peter Benardos and Independent Productions (AU)
results.brief_description: This film follows the drama of an Australian entertainment family, the Wildes. Kit Taylor and June Salter star as mother and son with a domain that stretches beyond the circus tent, encompassing the theatre, a wild animal park and the boardroom jungle. The future of the family seems stable, with the children being groomed to assume a position in the entertainment business. Their future is threatened by an unsavoury affair and a visiting Russian ballet troupe. Also starring Martin Vaughan, Lenore Smith, Warwick Moss, Alan Lee and Ivar Kantis.

results.title: Getting even: women in Australian politics
results.brief_description: In 1894 South Australia became one of the first places in the world to grant women the right to vote and first in the world to allow them to stand as candidates for political office. In 1902, the first Parliament of Australia granted white women the right to vote and to stand for election. Despite this, only 61 women have been elected to Federal Parliament in Australia to date. This film looks at why women’s efforts for greater representation have been continually frustrated, and asks what it is that motivates those women who have made it into the main political game. Female politicians from across the political spectrum talk about their experiences in the ‘boy’s club’ of Australian politics. Australia’s first female Premiers, Carmen Lawrence and Joan Kirner, reflect on their experiences of working at the top of State politics. Bronwyn Bishop, Cheryl Kernot, Amanda Vanstone and others, reveal what lies behind the public face of today’s female politicians. This film also examines the future for women in power, and examines the strategies being used by both major political parties to redress the gender imbalance in our parliaments. The film asks what it really takes for a woman to make it in politics. Has the hard won vote been an effective tool for change or has the political system acted to limit women’s influence? Narrated by Gillian Jones.

results.title: The War room
results.creator_credit: D.A. Pennebaker, Chris Hegedus, Frazer Pennebaker, Wendy Ettinger, R.J. Cutter, Cyclone Films, Mc and Ettinger Films and Pennebaker Associates
results.brief_description: DA Pennebaker was a leading figure in the development of cinema-verite documentary, and in this fascinating film he turns his cameras on the campaign to elect Clinton for President in the 1992 US election. As we follow the campaign from Democrat preselection in New Hampshire to Clinton’s eventual ascendancy to the White House, what becomes clear is the paramount importance of the media’s role in contemporary American politics. The focus of the film is on Campaign Manager, James Carville, and the Communications Director, George Stephanopoulos, who led and directed the campaign. These two ferociously intelligent and dedicated men are aware of the complex and difficult questions concerning American democracy in the post Cold-War era, but their battle is attempting to address these issues in a society obsessed with the superficial and simplistic dominance of media images.

results.title: Death of a nation: the Timor conspiracy
results.creator_credit: David Munro and Central Independent Television (UK)
results.brief_description: Written and presented by famed Australian journalist, John Pilger, this confronting documentary looks at the history of Indonesia’s occupation of East Timor. Since the 1975 invasion of this tiny island, the Indonesian military government has enacted a policy of genocide which has resulted in over 200,000 deaths and the attempted dismantling of the Timorese language, culture and identity. Much of this documentary was filmed undercover since, as the film makes vividly clear, one of the means by which the Indonenesian government has used to legitimise the occupation is through a blanket censoring of media images about and from East Timor. One of the most chilling aspects of this documentary is the evidence presented of the tacit assistance the governments of Australia, Great Britain and the United States have given to the invasion and occupation, an occupation which has seen some of the most barbaric human rights abuses of the twentieth century. The video includes interviews with former Western ambassadors to Indonesia; survivors of torture; and with FRETELIN guerrilla fighters who are still resisting the Indonesians without the assistance of any outside aid.
